thread.section_title: Foreign and national political news and analysis - San Francisco Chronicle
thread.title: GOP, Dems moving in opposite directions after a pivotal week
thread.title_full: GOP, Dems moving in opposite directions after a pivotal week - San Francisco Chronicle

author: Steve Peoples and Lisa Lerer, Associated Press
title: GOP, Dems moving in opposite directions after a pivotal week
text: Photo: Evan Vucci, AP Democratic presidential candidate, former Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton, accompanied by Virginia Gov. Terry McAuliffe, smiles and waves as she arrive for a campaign rally, Friday, Oct. 23, 2015, in Alexandria, Va. Democratic presidential candidate, former Secretary of State... WASHINGTON (AP) — After a pivotal week, the presidential race has become a tale of two parties on sharply different trajectories: Hillary Rodham Clinton has tightened her grip on the Democratic nomination while Republican concern is reaching new heights. Some officials are even considering what could turn into a GOP civil war to stop Donald Trump — with no fallback option. Democratic presidential candidate, former Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton, accompanied by Virginia Gov. Terry McAuliffe, smiles and waves as she arrive for a campaign rally, Friday, Oct. 23, 2015, in Alexandria, Va. Democratic presidential candidate, former Secretary of State... WASHINGTON (AP) — After a pivotal week, the presidential race has become a tale of two parties on sharply different trajectories: Hillary Rodham Clinton has tightened her grip on the Democratic nomination while Republican concern is reaching new heights. Some officials are even considering what could turn into a GOP civil war to stop Donald Trump — with no fallback option.
